title: Sri Lanka declares state of emergency after floods, landslides kill hundreds | The World | ABC NEWS
description: The death toll in Sri Lanka continues to rise with more than 355 people confirmed dead after strong winds and torrential rains from Cyclone Ditwah lashed the island. A state of emergency has been declared as the country reels from one of the worst flood disasters in two decades.  Bismarck Swangin, a spokesperson for UNICEF in Sri Lanka, tells The World about the current situation on the ground. title: Why surfers will have to pay to access Fiji's world-class breaks | The World | ABC News
description: Surfers wanting to catch a wave in Fiji could soon have to pay for the privilege as the government moves to repeal a unique law that opened up access to the country's world class reef breaks for tourists and locals alike. Foreign-owned resorts used to have exclusive access rights to famous waves like Cloudbreak, off Fiji's Tavarua Island, so you had to be a paying guest to ride them. Fiji surfing pioneer Ian Ravouvou Muller told The World's Girish Sawlani h welcomes the repeal and says he is looking forward to no longer feeling like a second-class citizen in his own country. #ABCTheWorld #ABCAsiaPacific  Subscribe: http://ab.co/1svxLVE  ABC NEWS provides around the clock coverage of news events as they break in Australia and abroad. title: Are NIMBYs and local councils a roadblock to solving Australia's housing crisis? | The Business
description: The public policy think tank, Committee for Economic Development of Australia (CEDA), believes Australia could increase its current housing stock by nine per cent, or a million homes, if just one in four standalone homes in the five biggest cities are developed into dual occupancies. It's calling on governments to do more to increase so called "gentle density" in the middle rings of Australia's biggest cities, by allowing more terrace housing, townhouses, low-rise apartments and dual occupancy. CEDA chief economist Cassandra Winzar joined The Business to discuss the first of CEDA's five new reports on housing.  She says some of the roadblocks in achieving higher density housing comes from local governments and so-called NIMBYs (Not In My Back Yard) local residents. She says right now local councils don't have an incentive to increase zoning, but one solution could be a "carrot and stick" approach where financial incentives are given to councils that make inroads to increase housing supply. She says when local governments don't meet zoning or supply requirements, the state or federal government should take over.  Cassandra Winzar says Australia can't keep building further and further out to keep up with growing demand and population growth, as it will put a lot of pressure on infrastructure. "We'll need new transport systems and that leads to long commutes and difficulties accessing services," she says. Ms Winzar says Australia is one of the least dense countries in the world. Even Sydney, Australia's highest density city, ranks at around 800th globally. She says Australians may need to reimagine what the average family home, aka the Australian dream, actually looks like, if they want to see a solution to the housing crisis. #ABCBusiness Subscribe: http://ab.co/1svxLVE  ABC NEWS provides around the clock coverage of news events as they break in Australia and abroad. title: Arson suspected as bushfires destroy home near Geraldton | ABC NEWS
description: An arson investigation has been launched after bushfires razed a home and threatened many others near Western Australia’s Geraldton.  Nick Morgan lost his cat when a blaze engulfed his house. Authorities suspect the fires were deliberately lit.  Bushfire conditions have eased as fire crews continue efforts to fully contain and control these fires. title: Rare cyclones to blame for deadly floods in Asia | ABC NEWS
description: The death toll from Cyclone Senyar and Cyclone Ditwah is rising fast, as more than 1,100 have been killed across Indonesia, Thailand, Malaysia and Sri Lanka. Flooding and landslides have claimed the lives of almost 600 people in Sumatra, as Indonesian President Prabowo Subianto is urged to declare a state of emergency to allow more access to aid and support.  Across the Malacca Strait, Thailand’s Prime Minister Anutin Charnvirakul is criticised for the government’s slow response to floods in the southern city of Hat Yai. Meanwhile, thousands of Sri Lankan army personnel have been deployed to assist families stranded floods. title: White House defends follow-up strike on boat in the Caribbean | ABC NEWS
description: The Trump administration has rejected war crime claims after the US military ordered a second strike that killed two survivors of a prior attack on an alleged drug-trafficking boat.  White House Press Secretary Karoline Leavitt says the admiral who ordered the follow-up strike on September 2 acted within his authority and ‘in accordance with the law of armed conflict’.  Democratic and Republican members of congress have both expressed concerns about the legality of Washington’s military attacks on suspected drug vessels from Venezuela. title: Is Ukraine any closer to a deal with Putin? | ABC News Daily podcast
description: In a flurry of peace talks over the last week, Ukrainian officials have been desperately trying to avoid an unjust deal with Russia being imposed on it.    They’ve been pushing back against a controversial 28-point proposal that would have required Ukraine to surrender significant territory, restrict the size of its defence force and give up on ambitions of joining NATO.    The US is leading the talks with both sides, but will Trump ultimately side with his Russian counterpart Vladimir Putin?   Today, international relations expert Rajan Menon on whether this latest round of diplomacy offers any real hope and what Kyiv may still have to give up.   Featured:    Rajan Menon, professor emeritus of international relations at the City College of New York

title: Toxic gas leak at Melbourne meat factory leaves 21 hospitalised | ABC NEWS
description: 21 workers have been hospitalised after a carbon monoxide leak at a meat-processing plant in Melbourne’s west.  The gas, which forced the evacuation of Auspork’s entire factory in Derimut, is believed to have come from meat preservation machines. Victorian firefighters had to wear full breathing apparatus due to dangerously high levels of carbon monoxide at the site. Ambulance Victoria says the incident could have been ‘so much worse’ as the gas is colourless and every lethal. title: Drugs like Ozempic endorsed by the WHO as a tool to treat obesity | ABC NEWS
description: The World Health Organization has released new guidance on glucagon-like peptide-1 (GLP-1) medications like Ozempic, Wegovy and Saxenda for adults with obesity, recommending their long-term, continuous use when clinically appropriate. While GLP-1 therapies represent one treatment option for adults with obesity, the WHO guideline emphasises that medicines alone will not solve the problem and a life-long treatment plan is necessary. title: National AI plan shifts from guardrails to economic opportunities | ABC NEWS
description: The federal government has released its National AI Plan, which will guide investment in data centres and worker training. The plan is a shift away from the former industry minister's plan for "mandatory guardrails" to protect against AI's worst harms. The government is opting to use existing framework instead.  An AI Safety Institute will monitor the technology from next year to provide advice on gaps in the law. title: Woolworths accused of using affordable housing schemes to push new developments | ABC NEWS
description: Woolworths is using New South Wales and Victorian development fast-track schemes to push ahead with new supermarket and apartment projects opposed by local councils. The schemes allow developers to bypass local planning rules and seek state government approval if they include an affordable housing component. Housing experts and councils want Woolworths to better integrate affordable housing into its design, saying one project's affordable housing annex amounts to a "poor door". title: Vinnies sends most charity waste to ACT landfill as overall disposal declines | ABC NEWS
description: St Vincent de Paul sent the most waste to ACT landfills last year, disposing of 376 tonnes of mostly broken or incomplete homewares.  Overall charity waste in Canberra fell by 38 per cent, with the Salvation Army's landfill contribution decreasing.  Vinnies is asking the public for higher-quality donations so more of its revenue can be spent on supporting people in need. title: More rainfall forecast after deadly Cyclone Ditwah slams Sri Lanka | ABC NEWS
description: Sri Lankan residents are bracing for more heavy rainfall after Cyclone Ditwah killed at least 355 people with hundreds still missing in the country.  The Sri Lankan government has deployed its armed forces to reach flood-stricken communities, while Pakistani and Indian armed forces joined flood relief efforts.  Damaged roads and mudslides have prevented humanitarian organisations from delivering much needed aid to stranded residents.  World Vision Sri Lanka’s national director Dhanan Senathirajah says the situation is a once-in-a-generation event.
